data.title: Benny Howell is Cricket’s Different Bowler by Red Inker With Jarrod Kimber
data.meta_description:
This week we have a T20 cricketer who in the last five years has the 4th best average and 4th best economy rate. Benny comes on to talk about his weird career so far, how he’s been overlooked despite his record, how baseball changed everything and what part his ADHD has played in him becoming the player he is. Not many medium pacers are part pitcher and part Dan Vettori, but Benny Howell is not like the others.
-
To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.
If you like this podcast, you may like the YouTube page https://www.youtube.com/jarrodkimberyt.
You can find Benny on twitter at https://twitter.com/bennytweets_and you can see him bowling guys a lot here [Benny Howell - Gloucestershire Cricket) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XdmDQ-DnJ0o
This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.
The theme tune is by Red Crickets https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.
data.text:
This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on India's chances of making the World Test Championship final again, how the West Indies' classic 4 man pace attack handled their workload, and how India's current bowling lineup sits in the history of bowling lineups, how AFL impacts grade cricket in Australia, how Jarrod reacted to the news about Shane Warne, the actual importance of the 'Ball Of The Century', whether Johnny Bairstow has found some solid form and different body types in cricket.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121. Jarrod also now has a Buy Me A Coffee link, for those who would prefer to support the shows there: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/jarrodkimber.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

This episode is about Shane Warne. It kind of had to be, right? I thought about doing an emergency podcast, but I didn't know how I would do it, would it just be me on my own, trying to emotionally process it all? And then my friend Jon Norman said why don't we do a podcast where we just chat about him until we run out of things to say. So here it is, two friends talking about Shane Warne for a very long time.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

Find Jon Norman on Twitter: https://twitter.com/FulhamJon.

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Greg Champion: https://youtu.be/IJRPuKDBk64.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on Ravichandran Ashwin versus the Indian spinner of old, and how the classic Indian spin quartet would fare in T20's, right arm bowlers coming around the wicket to left handers in Test cricket, the future of English wicket-keeping batsmen and what happens if Ben Stokes' career has already peaked, where the money that goes into the BCCI goes to, whether England have a chance in the West Indies, how the Australian teams are going to fare in the ODI World Cup in NZ and in the Test series in Pakistan, the continued prevalence of 'moneyball' cricket in franchise leagues, and how the ICC T20 rankings work.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121. Jarrod also now has a Buy Me A Coffee link, for those who would prefer to support the shows there: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/jarrodkimber.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

-

This episode we look at the bowling of Axar Patel under an actual microscope. And I do mean that fairly literally, as we have a scientist, Himanish Ganjoo, to come and take a look at Axar's data. We look at his height, angle, spin, lack of flight, sweeps, types of SLA, DRS, drift, failure to spin away and Axar's hang time.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

Find Himanish on Twitter: https://twitter.com/himanishganjoo

Check out his article here: [Training the Hawk-Eye on Axar Patel: Angular, Anomalous] (https://deeppoint.substack.com/p/understanding-axar-patel-angular)

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on opening in T20's, batting in the PSL, Rovman Powell's ongoing form against spin, fielding a team of all-rounders, who is India's support spinner for the T20 World Cup, Jarrod's pick for the most important type of players in a draft, racism in cricket across the world and the role of translators and pronunciation across the cricketing world, leadership in cricket and what signs you can read into to evaluate a well structured team, Steve Smith's role as the 'fixer' and the stubborness of male cricketers, how England could use Broad and Anderson better when overseas and how the role of anchor has changed in T20 cricket.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121. Jarrod also now has a Buy Me A Coffee link, for those who would prefer to support the shows there: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/jarrodkimber.

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

This is the 100th episode of Red Inker (sorta), and I wanted to do something a bit different here, so I have looked at the first time I ever sat in a team dug out. When I was a journalist covering Hong Kong in two matches against the Netherlands. It involves the ICC kicking me out, a man pissing while breaking protocol and me dreaming of a job that never existed.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on mental strength, the differences in stamina between Test and T20 cricket, how players choose which format they want to focus on, how much you can improve a players fielding, the dichotomy of Aaron Finch, some thoughts on New Zealand vs South Africa, why the top of off stump is such a target and the quality of the Pakistan Super League.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121. Jarrod also now has a Buy Me A Coffee link, for those who would prefer to support the shows there: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/jarrodkimber.

This episode is on Australia'swin in the '99 World Cup from the perspective of a fan. And so we only went and got the creator of the TV show Wilfred, Adam Zwar, to talk us through it. We talk Sting, Shane Warne's hurt feelings, Glenn McGrath at first change, Neil Johnson, comedy writing, South Africa, Lance Klusener's power, Steve Waugh's sledging and two of the greatest ODI’s ever.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreonpage. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

You can buy Adam Zwar’s book here.https://www.amazon.co.uk/Twelve-Summers-Adam-Zwar-ebook/dp/B09C7K3FJT

Follow Adam on Twitter here:https://twitter.com/adamzwar

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.comand https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on batsmen overcoming the current domination of the ball, how skills and stamina change in cricket over time, addressing the class imbalance in county cricket, negative bowling lines and whether cricket suffers from it's own laws, how unorthodox techniques fit into the overall cricket picture, what role Jarrod likes in the commentary box, the fates of Broad and Anderson, the Cricinfo Greatest ODI Bowlers of All Time list, what fed into Justin Langer being removed as Australian coach and The Grade Cricketer's take on it, and how friendships and relationships work inside of cricket teams.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

This episode of Red Inker is about bowling at the death, so I got on the bloke who has bowled there more than almost anyone alive. Jade Dernbach and I chat about slower balls, yorkers, scoops, social media, pressure, putting your hand up, bouncers, and the need for three good balls.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on analysis and the role of captaincy through the ages, space for ads in sports coverage, Jarrod's filmmaking background in his content making, reasons for Kuldeep's return and the state of spinners in the Indian side, how the speed that spinners bowl at has changed, and Jarrod's thoughts on the West Indies vs England series.

-

This week we’re talking about the weird last 12 months of Irish cricket, so we only went and got the captain on. Andy Balbirnie and I talk about beating South Africa, pinch blockers, losing to the USA, the T20 World Cup and what beating the West Indies means to Irish cricket.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreonpage. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on swing in the Women's game and the supposed 'optimum swinging pace', Jarrod's sense of humour and his interviewing demeanor, the future of cricket Youtube, Harsha Bhogle's comment on how easy it is for India to be the best team in the world right now, the progress of both teams in the Eng Vs WI T20 series, how distance can affect the 'heart' in cricketers' lives, whether bowlers impact matches more than batters and Jarrod's thoughts on Mahela Jayawardene's post-playing career.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

This episode of Red Inker is about the structure of English cricket, which has become one of the many narratives about how England lost the Ashes. So I got on cricket analyst Dan Weston who works for a county to talk about his plans to change it. We discuss #SilverwoodOut, red ball scheduling, incentives for player development, transfer fees, three divisions, four overseas, moving List A cricket and the medium-fast middle aged-glut.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

You can check out Dan’s Twitter here: https://twitter.com/SAAdvantage and his Substack here: https://danweston.substack.com/p/structural-change-for-english-red

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on over rates in T20's and cricket in the Olympics, what young wicketkeepers should focus on, bowlers having a better average in international cricket over first class cricket, why hit wicket counts as a bowler's wicket, generational cricket talents inspiring the same skills in players in their origin country (or not), whether 'thinking' crickets are actually intelligent people, what countries like New Zealand are doing to be so successful with such a low playing population, what sort of 'league' structure works best for cricket, what to say to a pre-Ashes Joe Root to help make the series more competitive, whether a better system than Duckworth/Lewis exists for score prediction, and how internal competitive culture can affect a team on the field.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

This episode is all about Ross Taylor. Now that his career is over, I thought it was a great time to look back. So I brought on one of the best New Zealand cricket journalists, Dylan Cleaver, to talk about him. We chat about his origin story, middle class cricket, Pacific Islands players, slogging, Martin Crowe, Kane Williamson, Brendon McCullum, his record in Tests, his even better career in ODIs and the fragility he had when he started his innings.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

If you like this podcast, you may enjoy other things I create, check them all out at https://linktr.ee/jarrodkimber.

You can check out Dylan’s Substack here: https://dylancleaver.substack.com

This podcast is edited, mixed and produced by Nick McCorriston, he's at https://www.nickamc.com and https://www.twitter.com/nickamc.

The theme tune is by Red Crickets: https://freemusicarchive.org/music/Red_Crickets/Red_Crickets.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on the curious case of Alex Carey, bowling like Jasprit Bumrah, what Clarrie Grimmett and Bill O'Reilly might have been like in T20's, whether the 1st or the 6th ball in the over makes any difference, what the role of the IPL Team Director is, Hardik Pandaya's bowling, how much age plays into captaincy selections, how the 3rd Test in SA against India is going and how SA are shaping up for the future, what Jarrod thinks a good keeper is, and how the pinch hitting role is going (or isn't going) in cricket.

-

This episode of Red Inker is a story I have wanted to tell for ages, how I grew up in Melbourne in the 1990’s as a young legspinner when Shane Warne was Shane Warne.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on 'golden arm' bowlers, why Mitch Santner and Ashton Agar are more successful in limited overs cricket than Test cricket, the enigma of Rassie van der Dussen, New Zealand without Kane Williamson, counter-attacking on difficult pitches, the downfall of Ed Smith at the ECB and the ongoing search for a Test all-rounder.

-

This episode of Red Inker is the end of year review. In a now annual tradition, I have brought on a friend, Vithushan Ehantharajah, to chat about it. We discuss every Test team in the world, but also, the Taliban, SA admin, Yorkshire, Pakistan at home, Burl’s shoes, Arthur’s shorts, Paine’s penis and Shaheen’s hair.

-

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on England's batting, my goodness there are alot of questions about England's batting, the current South African team in red and white ball, the systems that make (or don't make) international cricketers, the 'mindset' of batsmen, who the next candidates are to become Test playing nations, what Jarrod notices and notates while watching cricket, and how to convince people that the quality of bowling in Tests has gone up in the last 5 years.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

This episode we look at whether first class records are great predictors for batting success. So I got on someone who had written about that recently, Jack Hope from the Cricket Podcast. We look at stats, scouts, conditions, preparation, why players average more in Tests than First Class sometimes and also the whole Vaughan/Trescothick anomaly.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on Ollie Pope vs Marnus Labuschagne in regard to average, Ollie Pope's batting position, cricket content on Youtube, England's treatment of spinners, the concept of 'clutch' moments in cricket, England's treatment of fast bowlers, Jarrod's opinions of England's issues and overseas' teams success in South Africa.

-

Each week, Jarrod Kimber hosts a live talk show on Spotify Greenroom, a live chat app that you can use to talk with Jarrod. You can join the conversation over there each week, just download Spotify Greenroom on your phone, and follow Jarrod Kimber.

This episode we talk to a player from the 1986/87 Ashes series who played for England. He was recently part of Auddy's Inside the Tour podcast on that Test series, and we got him on to discuss his career, moving counties, playing Malcolm Marshall, facing cricket's first unplayable left-armer Bruce Reid, Merv Hughes, playing cricket in South Africa during apartheid and his fiery temperament.

-

To support the podcast please go to our Patreon page. https://www.patreon.com/user?u=32090121.

This week on Wagon Wheel, Jarrod answers questions from our loveable Patreon sponsors, and questions from our attendees on the wobble ball, other fast bowling variations, a second tier of Test Match cricket, fairness of selection, the BCCI/Kohli saga, Jarrod's selections for England in Adelaide, a lower grade T20 competition in Australia, England's spin predicament, leg spinners in Tests, Mickey Arthur's resignation as Sri Lankan coach and the Butler/Foakes conundrum and what Butler may choose to do in the future.

-

This episode we look at why Bangladesh bat so slow, and so since part of the problem is left-arm finger spin, I got on Bangladesh's greatest left-arm finger spinning journalist, Mohammad Isam.
